text: Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace and Miss Wulla Jean pose with th girls on the front porch of the house as a photographer takes their picture with an old flash-powder camera.

Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace picked it out for Miss Wulla Jean and her girls in 1910 when they moved there from over the hardware store on Main Street. We pan down through the leaves of a tree to reveal two gi working in a little garden by the side of the house. It h the appearance of a turn-of-the-century ladies college as the other girls cut flowers, sit around the grape arbor a sun-dry their long hair. (NOTE: We can bleed in the color slowly beginning with black and white, then sepia, then full color during the 1940's.)
(singing) Oh, the little house lay in a Green Texas glade Where the trees were as coolin' As fresh lemonade Soft summer wind Had a trace of perfume And a fan was turnin’ In every room.

We see the old ceiling fans turning, followed by several shots through the fans of the girls making love under the sheets, squeaking mattress shots, bouncing bedsprings, wi a chamber pot under the bed.
Twenty fans were turnin' They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin’ In every room Fevers were a~burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.

Miss Wulla Jean stands at the front door welcoming custom entering the house. We see the keys of a pianola start playing ragtime as the girls and customers break into a turn-of-the-century-style dance.

Miss Wulla Jean had a strict set of rules but she liked her ladies, as she called them, to treat her customers real good. The dancing continues, as Miss Wulla Jean makes sure her girls are behaving in a ladylike way.

She put a pianola in the parlor to sorta help break the ice. A feller could ask a girl to dance or if he held back a little, she'd ask him. And pretty soon they'd get a little business going «~ two dollars worth. The dance ends with a couple upstairs falling into bed.
Doughboys are coming and going.
By the First World war, it was one of the better-known pleasure palaces in all Texas.
A girl takes a cookie sheet from the kitchen oven and wal out to the garden.
And as the girls baked cookies....
The girl passes by other girls knitting socks, packing cookies, writing letters and wrapping bandages for the Re Cross.
..and knitted socks for the guys at the front, the soldiers there bragged of the little house back home.
(singing) It had nice watermelons All covered with vines And a vegetable garden A few slender pines White painted fence With the roses in bloom And a fan was turnin’ In every room.

location: A ROOM IN THE CHICKEN RANCH

text: A girl is washing a DOUGHBOY'S privates in a hand basin.
Miss Wulla Jean insisted that each girl check her customer real good for the clap and wash him off with soap and warm water. Some of the fellas claimed that was the best part.
Ooocoweeeeeh! The Doughboy takes off his hat and throws it off screen right.

The hat (now a straw boater) lands on a hat tree standing the parlor. The Doughboy (now with longer hair) is welcom by Wulla Jean at the front door. INT. CHICKEN RANCH PARLOR - NIGHT - 1920 il We pull back from a new phonograph to reveal couples danc around it -- letter-sweatered college boys and bow-tied businessmen. NARRATOR . When the war ended, Miss Wulla Jean celebrated with a new phonograph in the parlor. The girls Charleston with their customers and we intercut with the bouncing beds upstairs.

location: AN UPSTAIRS ROOM IN THE CHICKEN RANCH

text: A half-dressed couple ends the dance by kicking the door closed. The music fades out and a plaintive harmonica tak over. We pan to an open window and see the dilapidated grape arbor, while wind and dust blow across the landscap
But prosperity blew away like a dust storm and in came the Hoover Depression.
Extreme long shot of the little house looking very bleak. hot, dusty wind is blowing as an old, broken-down car mak its way down the long drive away from the house.

location: A ROOM IN THE CHICKEN RANCH

text: A GIRL shuts the window, closing out the blowing wind. Sh turns to a young farmer, who is carrying a gunny sack.
Now, I'm sorry, honey. I gotta have my three dollars first. Miss Wulla Jean don't allow no honeyfuggin' 'til I pay my rent. The farmer picks up the sack and reaches inside.
It wasn't always easy to come up with three dollars, especially during the hard times. The farmer pulls a chicken out of the bag and holds it up proudly for barter. The Girl sighs:

well, you just keep that in the bag and I'll take it out back soon as we're finished. INT. CHICKEN RANCH PARLOR ~ NIGHT - 1930'S 1s We see some girls accepting payment from three farmers wi chickens on their laps.
And so the girls began accepting poultry in trade -- one bird, one lay....
The girls are feeding the chickens and as we pull back we see they have built a temporary pen full of several hundr birds.
And that's how the place got its name -~ The Chicken Ranch!

The camera pulls back from the new jukebox where couples jitterbugging around it to a big band sound. Miss Wulla Jean nails up a wartime portrait of F.D.R. in hallway. A bugle calls and upstairs a young customer jumps out of The girls and their guests, now dressed in World War II uniforms, dance down the steps and out the front door.  18 19 20 21 22 23 24
Int’. CHICKEN RANCH KITCHEN ~ DAY - 1940'S In a replay of the 1914 cookie-baking sequence, a girl ta a cookie sheet from the oven and walks outside.

Out in the victory garden, the girls, thirty years later, are still doing their patriotic bit for the boys at the front. One of the girls, sealing a letter with a lipstick kiss, turns off-screen at the sound of an approaching car
Fifties-style music accompanies the arrival of a converti full of crew cut college boys. They pull up to the porch a young black woman called JEWEL waves them a welcome.

Jewel takes the boys' money and they file through the fro door joining other customers dancing rock and roll in the parlor. Miss Wulla Jean is replacing Truman's picture wit Eisenhower's. InT. A ROOM IN THE CHICKEN RANCH - NIGHT - 1950'S Three guys, careful to keep their ducktail hairdo's neatl combed, dance with their girls and somersault them into b

Jewel passes a portrait of Kennedy as she walks over to Sheriff Jack Roy and his deputies leaving with two low- life characters they have just arrested. Miss Wulla Jean congratulates hin, while in the parlor customers dance to the jukebox.

Jewel and Miss Wulla Jean are at the “presidential Wall" taking down the picture of L.B.J. Miss Wulla Jean ages fr standing with a cane to sitting in a wheelchair while we cuts of Jewel putting up Nixon and taking him down, putti up Ford and taking him down, and then finally, at Miss Wu Jean's insistance, putting up L.B.J. to be nailed to the wall and left there permanently.

For over three generations the little house went about its business while the town prospered, and those folks that couldn't approve of the Chicken Ranch at least decided it fell under the principle of peaceful coexistence. Miss Wulla Jean nods with satisfaction at her favorite Te president, puts down her stereopticon on the hall table a Jewel wheels her away. We push in on the stereopticon and see it contains the old sepia shot of the little house ta so many long years ago.
Course, if you grew up anywhere in Texas, you knew at an early age that they were selling something out there other than poultry.

The helicopter shot. As we swoop across the countryside a up toward the little house on the hill, the music becomes wilder and picks up speed. Two cars, a farmer's pickup an an Army jeep are flying up the old dirt road to the front the house.
Twenty fans were turnin' They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin' In every room Fevers were a-burnin' - They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.
The customers come in the door and, grabbing the girls, d the Texas Twist dance through the house.
Twenty fans were hummin' They were hummin' Twenty fans were hummin' In every room Customers were comin' They were comin' And they had to have A way to cool down.  27 28 29
Customers and girls dance in the open back courtyard, whi upstairs fans are turning at a faster speed and the beds bouncing to their rhythm.
Twenty fans were turnin’ They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin’ In every room. Fevers were a-burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.
The satisfied customers are leaving, getting into the collegiate Volkswagons and executive Pontiacs.
Y'all come back now, hear? The customers respond to Jewel's cry as if asked for an encore, and so...they turn and run into the house, nearly knocking Jewel over in the process.
The music doubles in tempo and so do the fans. A montage fun filled sexual shenanigans, cutting from the dancing i the parlor to the bouncing beds upstairs.

Twenty fans were turnin' They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin' in every room Fevers were a-burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down. Twenty fans were hummin’ They were hummin' Twenty fans were hummin' In every room. Customers were comin' They were comin' And they had to have A way to cool down.  30 31 32 33 34
A cowboy, still wearing his hat in bed, is ecstatically coming to a climax.
His shadow is silhouetted on the window shade and we hear his excited Voice.

I'm comin'! I'm comin'! Thank you. Thank you, Jesus. We pan off the window up to the metal rooster weather van on the roof and as horizon, the names the morning sun breaks across the of our stars flash across the screen.... Burt Reynolds... Dolly Parton... The Best
Little Whorehouse in Texas!
The rest of the Main Title Credits play over beautiful vistas of the East Texas countryside while the orchestra gives a zippy taste of some of the songs to come.
We pan down from the sky, past the Texas flag and take a full shot of the Gilbert town square.
When Sheriff Jack Roy Wallace retired, about ten years ago now, Deputy Ed Earl Dodd was elected to the job. Everybody likes Ed Earl..;.
The mayor, RUFUS P. potential customer tires. POINDEXTER, is showing a car to a while the customer's wife kicks the
The mayor, Rufus P. Poindexter, leans on him to keep the town running peacefully....
EDSEL MACKEY is pulling the proof pages off the presses.
Edsel Mackey, the editor of the Gilbert Gazette, has supported Ed Earl in every Ccampaign....
DULCIE MAE, a not unattractive widow in her early forties is supervising the breakfast.

And over at the cafe, the owner, Miss Dulcie Mae...well she is kind of prejudiced cause everyone knows she's been stuck on Ed Earl for years, ever since her husband passed away. She has a fine son, Billy, and.... Dulcie Mae is pouring coffee and she looks off at someone shouting in the town square. The customers look off, too.
Humm...What's that commotion out there?

THREE NESTERS playing dominoes in the gazebo turn their heads and look off as a hysterical MODENE ENNIS, sporting tight new permanent hairdo, runs across the street and up the steps of the courthouse.
Dammit! Dammit!
Oh, it's that town troublemaker, Modene Ennis, heading up to Ed Earl's office to give him a hard time again.
Modene dashes down the corridor, screaming.
Ed Earl! Ed Earl! She walks through the swinging door, past a startled RITA CROWELL, Ed Earl's gray-haired secretary.
Morning, Rita. DEPUTY FRED WILKINS is coming out of Ed Earl's office. He is swept back inside by the force of Modene's entrance.

Morning, Deputy Fred. She plants herself in front of the sheriff's desk, where ED EARL, leaning back in his chair, is whittling chains f a block of wood. Behind his desk hang portraits of all ni County Sheriffs ending with Jack Roy Wallace and Ed Earl Dodd.
Ed Earl, now listen up. You've got yourself a problem. Ed Earl looks up and tips his hat back on his head.
Morning, Miss Modene.

It just ain't right for Tucker Faylin to keep on doing this. I've talked to him. I've talked to you. There is a law in this county, Sheriff, and it's up to you to see that it's carried out. Ed Earl stands up and grabs his gun and holster.
I'll take care of it.
Do you want me to bring the rifle?
Put it down, Fred. I've handled this situation before.

A mule is standing in front of Miss Modene's car, with hi behind sitting on the highly-polished hood. A few townspeople have gathered around to look at the bizarre sight. Ed Earl, with his guns strapped on, looking like he's goi out to meet Billy the Kid, walks across the street from t Courthouse. Behind him are Rita and Deputy Fred; while Miss Modene, keeping up beside him, continues to babble.

I came out of the beauty shop and there he was, standing right in front of my car. I tried to back up, but I couldn't, so I went forward slowly, figuring that he'd move, but he just buckled up his back legs and sat right down on my hood. The group stops as Modene points at her predicament. Ed Earl is not fazed at all. He walks up to the mule and addresses him, man to man.
Mornin', mule. I'm Sheriff Ed Earl Dodd and I've got a request here for you to, pardon the expression, move your ass.
MANSEL, the barber, is giving C.J. VERNON, the insurance salesman, his morning shave. C.J. looks out the window. C.J. What's going on out there?
Ed Earl's talking to that jackass again. C.J. You mean the mule or Miss Modene? They both laugh and settle back. EXT. BEAUTY SHOP - DAY 4i Ed Earl continues addressing the mule.
I'm sorry you're taking it this way. I don't want to lose my _ temper because, as folks will tell you, that can be real trouble.
Sheriff, you got to get him off there. Where's Tucker Faylin?
Why don't you give him a tug?

Shut up, Fred. Now, listen, mule. I don't want to get physical with you. I want to be real polite. So, I'm asking you for the last time...Move! The mule stares back at him and is singularly unimpressed Ed Earl gives up.

Okay. If that's your decision. He takes a cheroot from his breast pocket and puts it in mouth. He strikes a match on his belt buckle and lights t cigar. Modene is very agitated at Ed Earl's calm and his lack of progress.
What are you going to do, Sheriff? I'm expected back home. Ed Earl walks out of frame. A quick cut of the mule's tai being lifted off the hood. The mule looks over his should to see what's happening.
Sheriff, are you listening to me? LOUISE MAPLES, an elderly lady of the town and a staunch supporter of Ed Earl, butts in.
Hush, Modene. The Sheriff knows what he's doing.

Don't hush me, Louise. I've spent fifteen dollars on this permanent and I'm so upset it's beginning to lose it's shape. The sudden loud whinny of the mule startles them both. Deputy Fred and Rita back up in fright.
Mansel and C.J. look out the window.
The three nesters look up from their game.
A long shot of the mule as it gallops wildly across the t square.
Dulcie Mae glances up from the counter as Ed Earl enters sits down.
Morning, Ed Earl.
Morning, Dulcie. She begins to pour him a cup of coffee.
I heard all that noise out there. How did you get that animal to move?
Well, Dulcie Mae, the way to handle an animal is like my daddy used to tell me. He used to say....
There's a crash from the kitchen and the COOK comes runni in.
You won't believe what I saw.
What's that?
I just saw a mule run by my window blowing cigar smoke out of his ass. Dulcie Mae looks at Ed Earl. He picks up his coffee.
That's what my daddy told me. Dulcie Mae laughs.
The sun goes down over a long shot of the Chicken Ranch.
Just about the time Ed Earl took over his job as Sheriff, Miss Wulla Jean passed away.

Jewel, now more mature, is greeting customers at the fron door and taking their money. Miss Wulla Jean's black crep draped portrait hangs on the wall and couples are still dancing to the old jukebox in the front parlor.
She bequeathed her place in her will to her favorite working girl, Mona Stangley, who, you might say, had worked her way up from the bottom. ...
The door opens and, from a low angle, we see a glamorous pair of legs walk along the corridor.
No one knew much about her, where she came from or why, but they did know she ran the same tight ship and carried on the same tradition of quality. 45 46 47 48  49

We follow the woman until she turns at the top landing. Customers at the front door turn their heads and look up. MONA STANGLEY, glamorously gowned, smiles a welcome and begins walking down the stairs. Miss Mona

(singing) It's just a little old Bitty pissant country place Ain't nothin' much to see No drinking allowed We get a nice quiet crowd Plain as it can be. It's just a piddly squattin' ole Time country place Ain't nothin' too high-toned Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill But there's nothing dirty goin' on!
Nothin' dirty goin' on. walks into the parlor.

We get simple farmers Local businessmen Congress folks from Austin Young boys lookin' for sin Now we used to get a lot of roughnecks When the oil boom was high But payday'd get a little rowdy Thank God the field run dry.

It's just a little bitty pissant Country place Nothin' much to see No drinkin' allowed We get a nice quiet crowd Plain as it can be. It's just a piddly squattin' Old time country place Nothin' too high-toned Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill But there's nothin' dirty goin' on!

I don't hire no married girls They're not on the ball ‘Cause they got homes and husbands They're not stable at all ‘Cause they don't understand a thing About a proper business day Now what's the point of Openin' up the store If you give the goods away? It's just a little bitty pissant Country place Nothin' much to see No drinkin' allowed We get a nice quiet crowd Plain as it can be. A girl in the back nudges a guy to keep his hip flask hid in his jacket.
It's just a piddly squattin' Old time country place Nothin' too high-toned Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill But there's nothin' dirty goin' on!
All the girls, in their nighties and bathrobes, are down breakfast, but Jewel seated at the big table. The Cook has a helper, is in charge of serving.

Keep your language clean, girls Keep your bedrooms neat Don't hang around the town cafe Or say 'hi' on the street. Mind your P's and Q's And manners And you don't need no other tools ‘Cause every girl who lives here knows My special no-no rules.
Yeah, every girl who lives here knows Miss Mona's no-no rules.
Ruby Rae, start ‘em.
Beds are not to be wallowed in That's the kind of thing That big fat lazy hogs do.
And it don't make money. Beatrice....
And I won't tolerate no tyin' Up my telephone with other People's business.
Eloise, honey....
And please don't show us No tattoos, no hearts and flowers On your thigh.
It's downright tacky.
Brands belong on cattle And that ain't what we're Sellin' at Miss Mona's.
Do you catch my drift? I pay the food and the rent And the utilities You keep your mind on your work Responsibilities Don't let your mouth overload your Capabilities And we can get along...Dawn....
Any bad habits you come in with Get rid of right now.
Taddy Jo....
I can't stand no chewin' gum It looks just like a cow.
Linda Lou..:-
Anyone takin' sick leave Oughta be real sure they're sick.
And every time you hear that bell.... Jewel rings the bell prominently displayed in the hall at the bottom of the stairs.
Better get here double quick!
It's the afternoon free time and while the girls lounge around outside in their day wear, Miss Mona continues singing.

And as for pimps, pimps are somethin' You don't need to get your daily Business done Are you listenin' good? So keep those leeches and bloodsuckers . Off the back road I know how to use a gun No one messes with my girls. One girl practices the flute, another ballet, another yog while another girl is sitting on the wooden swing reading book "How To Make Money In Real Estate".

And any questions you might have About the way I run this place Don't gripe and whine Behind my back Just tell me face-to-face I'm open-minded Say it all. Then go upstairs and pack The door's thata way.
The girls start coming out of their rooms and begin danci downstairs.
She pays the food and the rent and the Utilities We keep our mind on our work Responsibilities Don't let your mouth overload your Capabilities.
Mona pushes the sliding doors aside and steps out to gree a group of conventioneers.
And we can get along. (talking) Howdy, boys. Welcome to the Chicken Ranch,
Hello... Howdy, Miss Mona... Nice to see you....
Come on over here, I'd like you to meet my girls.
The music slow line, changes as the girls vamp down the stairs in a draped across the banister.
It's just a little bitty pissant Country place Nothin' much to see No drinkin' allowed We get a nice quiet crowd Plain as it can be.

GIRLS (Cont'd) It's just a piddly squattin' old time Country place Nothin' too high-toned Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill But there's nothin' dirty goin' on. Suddenly the place is full of customers who pair off with the girls and begin dancing.

It's just a little bitty pissant Country place Nothin' much to see No drinkin' allowed We get a nice quiet crowd Plain as it can be. It's just a piddly squattin' old time Country place Nothin' too high-toned. The girls begin taking their customers up the stairs as t tempo doubles.
Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill.
Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill.
Jes' lots of good will And maybe one small thrill.
But there's nothin' dirty goin' on.
The girls come running up the stairs and take their guest inside their rooms.
Nothin' dirty goin' on! All doors slam.  56 57 58 59

A rooster standing on a fence post crows to greet the ris sun. Last night's guests come straggling out, feeling spe but happy. The girls yawn and stretch and wave good-bye from the porch or the upstairs windows. Everybody looks very contented.

And so the Chicken Ranch continued to live in peace with the town and the folks there took secret pride in the oldest established, permanently operating, non-floating whorehouse in Texas...that is, until about a year ago last Thanksgiving.
In a cloud of dust, Ed Earl speeds his sheriff's car down country road.
Ed Earl looks very agitated as if he were chasing a crimi He glances at his watch and steps on the gas.
Rita, seated at her desk, has finished writing out a rece
I can't tell you how thrilled we are with this contribution, Miss Mona. Here's your receipt. She hands the receipt to Mona, who is standing at the cou in front of her.
Thank you, Rita.
Those kids will be so excited. And the Mayor, too. Why, the town council will probably vote you another plaque.
I hope not, Rita. I've gota closet full of them now. Dulcie Mae steps in from the corridor and stops when she sees Mona.
Hello, Dulcie Mae. You know Miss Mona.
Yes, of course. We've met. Mornin’.
How are you?
Isn't this wonderful. Miss Mona has capped the goal for the Little League Fund Campaign.
How nice. On behalf of my son and his teammates, I'd like to thank you.
Tell them I'll be well repaid when they take the championship this year. Good-bye, Rita. Mona starts for the door.
I'm sorry the Sheriff wasn't here to thank you. He drove over to Meritsville. He'll be gone all afternoon.
Well, tell him i said hi. (to Dulcie) "Bye.
‘Bye.
'Bye. Mona leaves.  60 61 62 63
Ed Earl continues racing across the countryside.
Mona is getting into her car as Deputy Fred drives up.
Hello, Miss Mona. Nice to see you.
Hello, Deputy Fred. You keeping an eye on my place at night?
Sure are. The Sheriff's real particular about the security out there.
Well, some night when you're not on duty you drop on by. I'm sure the girls would like to show their appreciation.
Oh, Miss Mona, shucks. You know I'm a married man.
Now, Fred, you think the cows don't appreciate the time off when the bull goes on over to the next pasture?
(blushing) Oh, Miss Mona. Mona laughs and drives out of town.
A closeup of Ed Earl as he continues driving.
His Sheriff's car speeds past camera.  64 65 66
Ed Earl turns his car off the highway and drives up to th front porch of a house. He gets out.
Ed Earl strides across the living room to the bedroom, se a jacket flung over a chair, fingers it for a moment, smi to himself, then flings open the bedroom door.
Ed Earl stops in the doorway and his face falls at what h sees.
Dammit! We cut and see a figure lying in bed in the darkened room The lights turn on. Mona is lying in his bed with a sheet pulled up coyly to her chin. She smiles at him.
What's the matter?
You've gotten into bed already.
So?
I've told you a hundred times, watching you undress is the best part.
The best part?
Well, maybe not the best part, but certainly in the top two.
Well then, Ed Earl.... She throws off the sheet and we see that she's lying in b fully clothed. Ed Earl laughs.
I'm glad I was late.
Me too. He starts toward the bed, but she bounces out and picks u package from her tote bag.

Now, just hold it for a second. I've got a surprise for you. I picked up a package this morning from the post office. It's the latest thing from Frederick's of Hollywood. She holds up a black shorty negligee. He isn't very impressed.
Not much to it.
I think I can fill it out. She goes into the bathroom. He laughs and shouts after he
I'll bet you can. He quickly undoes his tie and takes off his shirt.
I swear to God, Mona, there ain't a woman in the world that can get me as excited as you can. MONA (v.o.) Even after all these years we been meeting like this?
Every year with you, darlin', is like a minute of sheer happiness. MONA (v.0.) That's very sweet, Ed Earl.
Well, you bring out the romantic in me.
He undoes his belt and drops his pants. He looks up as Mo appears in the doorway. She looks stunning in her black negligee.
Woweeee! That was quick.
I've had a lot of practice getting in and out of my clothes. What do you think? She models it for him.
Hot damn, Mona, it makes me feel real sexy.
You don't look very sexy.
(taken aback) What do you mean? I look like I always look.
That's the problem. It's those damn boxer shorts. I can't stand the look of those droopy white drawers.
These? What's the matter with them? I always wear boxer shorts. I've worn them for years.
They look it.
This is a brand new pair. And what do you mean I don't look sexy? People have always said I look sexy. They say I have a sexy quality.
You do, but those boxer shorts don't. Now, look here. This is what I ordered expressly for you.
She takes a pair of black jockey shorts from her tote bag He shuffles over to her with his pants still around his b and takes a look at them.
Looks like a Japanese sling shot.
It's a pair of jockey shorts with little silver snaps on the side.
I'm not getting into those. They'd kill me.
They cost me twenty dollars, plus postage, Ed Earl, and I want you to wear them.
Twenty dollars for that little thing? You got screwed.
Come on, Ed Earl.
I'm not putting them on.
If they look half as good as I think they will, you won't have to keep them on for long.
Mona, I'm not going to wear that thing. They're ridiculous. They're embarassing.
They're sexy.
I said 'no' and that's the end of it.
Okay, then I'm getting dressed.
Okay, I'11 put them on.
He grabs them and, still shuffling, makes his way into th bathroom.
(muttering) Damn. They'll be like putting two bowling balls in a marble sack. Mona laughs and takes the phone off the hook. She goes to closet and brings out a pillow.
I saw Dulcie Mae in town today. Ed Earl talks from the bathroom. ED EARL (v.o0.) Oh, yeah?
I_ expect you're going out to her place for Thanksgiving dinner? ED EARL (v.0.) Don't I always?

Well, you better start checking that turkey, 'cause there's a hook inside that's gonna land you right over at the wedding chapel. ED EARL (v.0o.) Not me, Mona. I don't believe in that stuff. It don't work out.
Amen to that. Ed Earl sticks his head out around the door.
Ready?
I'm always ready.
Like a flash, Ed Earl runs out of the bathroom across the room, jumps into bed and pulls the sheet up to his chin. Mona laughs.
Oh, Ed Earl. Is that it?
Yeah. How was it?
But I hardly saw them.
That's too bad, because I ain't going to parade around this room like some damn model.
Come on, Ed Earl. Do it for me.
No.
I just want to take a look at them.
No. Mona lifts up the bottom of the sheet.
Come on, just a little peek.
No. She puts her hand under the sheet. Ed Earl jumps up.
Mona! Mona withdraws her hand and holds up the shorts in triump
That's what the little silver snaps are for.
(laughing) Come on over here and let me put a lip-lock on you. Ooops! Wait! I've gotta brush my teeth. He grabs the bedspread, wraps it around himself and hobbl into the bathroom. Mona laughs.
Oh, Ed Earl, I like a lot of things, but these afternoons with you have got to top the list.
Sing it to me, honey.
(singing) I like fancy frilly things High-heeled shoes and diamond rings Ragtime bands and western swing And sneakin' around with you.
(singing) I like beer and rodeos Detective books and dominoes Football games and Cheerios And sneakin' around with you.
Sneakin' around with you Goin' a round or two Doin’ what lovers do Whenever we're sneaking around.
I like lots of cash on hand And dirty jokes about the Fuller Brush Man.
I like stuff I understand Like sneakin' around with you.
I like a thrill that has no strings.
Friendship that don't ever change.
And laughter from the joy of things.
And sneakin' around with you We're just sneakin' around We're not chained and bound Sharin' the ups and downs Of lovers sneakin' around.
Oh, I like drive-in picture shows Kissin' long and lovin' slow.
The secret places lovers go Whenever they're sneakin' around I like the crazy things we try.
And the sexy things we fantasize.
And makin' out in broad daylight.
Sneakin' around with you Sneakin' around with you Keepin' it all brand new Gettin' the best of you Whenever we're sneakin' around.
Sneakin' around that's all.
I’m gonna lay down the law.
Watchin' the rise and fall Of lovers sneakin' around.
We're just sneakin' around.
Wetre just sneakin'.... The song ends with them sitting on the edge of the bed ju about to kiss. But this kiss is interrupted by a sudden loud knocking.
Deputy Fred is knocking at the front door.

The local people, according to their respective dispositi and allegiances, cheer or react in a shocked manner. Bill and his friends are delighted.
Git ‘im, Sheriff.
(chortling) He may be mean, but he's ours!

Three! No sawed-off little pecker is gunna accuse me of takin' a _ bribe and live to tell it, ‘cause I wear the badge in this goddamn county. So you listen good, you over-padded, televisin' turd, if I ever see you or any one of your other bastards in this town again, t'll knock you so flat you'll have to roll down your socks to shit.
That's tellin! him, Sheriff.
(laughing) Oh, my goodness! Ed Earl gets out his gun and points it at Melvin.

Now, get out of here, you goddamn wig-wearin' citified son-of-a-bitch! He fires his pistol into the air. Women scream, dogs bark and everyone starts to ecatter. The cameraman trips over camera and Melvin, in his hurry to flee, falls backward i

the fountain and almost loses his wig. Ed Earl keeps shoo The townspeople run for cover, put look on happily as Mel and the TV crew hop in their two trucks and drive away- E Earl puts his gun back in the holster and mutters proudly himself.

So long, pardner. He looks around -- the crowd comes out from hiding and gi him a wild ovation. Billy is thrilled and points Ed Earl out to his friends. BILLY . He's my friend. He's coming over to my house to watch the Aggie game. Ed Earl is accepting the adulation of the crowd. He gets into his car. Dulcie Mae comes over. ’ DULCIE MAE You were wonderful, Ed Earl.
Thanks, Dulcie.
We've finished serving lunch, but I did save you a piece of meatloaf. It's your favorite.
Well, no thank you. I have an official report to make about all this and I've got to go up to the Chicken Ranch and talk to Miss Mona.
Oh, of course.
Catch you later. Ed Earl drives off to the cheers of the citizens. We push in on Dulcie Mae's face. She knows he's going out to celebrate with Mona and that he is in love with her.

location: A TEXAS ROADSIDE BAR AND DANCE HALL

text: A fiddler is on the bandstand leading the band in a hoedo while the customers dance around the floor. Everyone is having a foot-stomping good time.
Mona and Ed Earl enter. She is ina simple dress and he is not in his uniform. They are in great high spirits and go over to the bar to order beer.

By the beers on the table we see the time has passed. The band is taking a break and we seque into a record playing the jukebox. Mona, sitting at the table by herself, looks around as Ed Earl comes up to her.
Well, listen to that, it's my favorite Bob Wills song.

I know. Why do you think I put it on? He offers her his hand. She smiles and takes it. They wal out to the dance floor and begin to dance as we hear Bob Wills sing "Faded Love." BOB WILLS (v.0.) (singing) As I look at the letters That you wrote to me It's you that I'm thinkin' of. As I read the lines That to me were so sweet I remember our faded love. Mona joins in singing with the record.
I’11 miss you darling More and more every day As heaven would miss the stars above. with every heartbeat I will think of you i remember our faded love. As they dance around the floor we:
Ea Earl drives by in his truck with Mona snuggled up besi im.  116 117
Mona looks up at Ed Earl and smiles contentedly.
We pull back from the campfire that Ed Earl has built by shore to reveal he and Mona lying up against a log and lo up at the heavens. They are quietly enjoying the peace of moment. Mona sighs.
Look at them stars. Ain't nothin‘ prettier than a Texas sky.
Ain't that the truth.
Hey! Did you see that shooting star?
Mmmm .
Do you think that might have been a spaceship? Do you believe in that sort of thing?

Oh, sure. There's all kinds of strange things happening. I seen some pictures once of those little guys from outer space. They're about two feet high, have bald heads, tiny little legs and they got no peckers.

well, then, I ain't interested and neither would any of my girls. You know, when I was little I used to dream about flying saucers coming down to get me and take me off to heaven. You know, like the angels. ‘And I looked and behold a whirlwind came out of the north...and out of the midst of the fire came the likeness of four living creatures.'
Oh, yeah. What are you talking about?
That's from Ezekiel. Haven't you ever heard of Ezekiel in the Bible?
gure, I've heard of the Bible. But the only Ezekiel I ever heard of is Ezekiel Peebles in the eighth grade. I busted his jaw once.
That was very Christian of you, Ed Earl. :
well, we were all Baptists in my family.
I never stayed with any one family long enough to become anything in particular. But I read the Bible and I do know about Jesus.
I think Jesus was a nice person. Must have been a good speaker.
You know, I knew a woman once who told me she had a vision of Jesus. He came right down and sat on the end of her bed one night. I believed her. I feel that could happen to me.
Well, if Jesus comes into your piace honey, all hell's gonna break oose.

(laughing) I guess you got a point, Ed Earl. But you know, Jesus was very good to Mary Magdalene and she was a fallen woman. Isn't that amazing. She was perhaps his best friend. ED EARL . You mean Mary Magdalene was Jesus' girlfriend?
Well, not the way you're thinking. But Jesus did like to have a good time. People seem to forget that. You know, he went to a wedding once
MONA (Cont'd) and they ran out of wine. So you know what he did? He turned some water into wine. .
Sounds like a man who knowed how to party.
Now, don't be sacrilegious, Ed Earl.
Oh, he knows I was kidding. He forgives me.
Yeah...I know he does. Ain't it funny. God can forgive you, but people can't. Why is that?
Because most people ain't too God-like, honey.
I know. I know. A pause as they look at the sky. Ed Earl begins to chuckl
That Melvin P. Thorpe is a sorry son-of-a-bitch.
(laughing) Well, you sure sent him packing. I'm proud of you.
You think he's really running for office?
Why?
Well, I haven't told this to anyone yet, but I'm thinking of running for the legislature myself.
You serious, Ed Earl?

Yeah, I'm serious. I've got my sights aimed higher than being a sheriff all my life. Besides, ! think I could do some good. A lot of people don't think an honest man can be elected, but I don't believe that. This is a great country and we've still got it in us.
Well, you've got my vote. I! might even go register.
1'd be a good politician, Mona. And you know why? Because I'd tell the truth. Nobody does that anymore and, by God, I'm going to give it a shot. .
I didn't know you had dreams that big, Ed Earl.
Well, it's one dream I believe I could pull off. People like me. It's natural to like me. You know, people like you, too. You'd be surprised if you took a poll around town.
Really?
I hear it all the time. You're a well-liked lady.
Well, I always believed if you see somebody without a smile, give then yours.
1 like that. Do you think I could borrow that slogan when I run for the legislature...'I always believed if you see somebody without a smile, give them yours.' ...I could put that on my card.
oh, Ed Earl. I guess I'm just not a person who believes in dreams. I believe in reality. Dreams have never gotten me anywhere.
But how about when you were a kid. You must have wanted to be something.
Promise you won't laugh?
sure.

I used to think I wanted to be a dancer. 1 wanted to be a ballerina. One of the first things I can remember was a little ballerina on top of a music box. I would just watch her for hours dancing round and round.
well, I don't think it's too late for you to be a ballerina.
Oh, hell, Ed Earl. I'm so top-heavy, I have a hard enough time balancing these now without getting up on my toes.
Mona, you're wonderful.
Thank you...you know, I don't see anyone except you, Ed Earl. Not anymore. You can't say the same, can you. /
I don't go to bed with anyone elise.
You don't?
Not for three years now. You didn't know that, did you?
CONTINUED - 5 ir
No, I didn't.
Well, I figure there's nothing better after you've had the best.
I like that. If I ever run for the legislature, I'm gonna put that on my card. They laugh. They kiss. They kiss again and fall into a passionate and loving embrace.
The Mayor is watching television.
Next up, Melvin P. Thorpe continues his expose on the Chicken Ranch with a violent demonstration in the Gilbert town square. The Mayor reacts to seeing the announcement on television
Great God from Goldsborough! Doreen. Doreen! Run git my heart pills!

In the darkened room the phone is ringing. It rings three or four times. A hand comes out from under the blankets, turns on the overhead light and answers the phone. It is Earl. He sticks his head out from under the blankets.
Yes. Yes?
The Mayor is on the telephone.
Ed Earl, you better turn on Channel 4. That Melvin P. Thorpe idiot has got you on TV again.  121
Ed Earl turns to Mona.
Honey, turn on the television. Channel 4. The Mayor says that Melvin P. Thorpe is spewing off at the mouth again. Mona reaches for the remote control for the TV on the nig table.
Calm down, Rufus, it can't be as bad as ali that. Mona turns on the television and we see Melvin seated at news desk giving his version of what happened in the Gilb town square.

What happened to me, as an individual, is not important. But what Sheriff Dodd did to a constitutionally licensed newsman and a good tax-paying American citizen is important! It calls up old dark versions of Mussolini's Brown Shirts and the Nazi terrors. I think the film speaks for itself. On the television screen we see an edited version of Ed Earl's speech: a tle bleep No sawed-off little bleep is gunna accuse me of takin' a bribe and live to tell it... (fires gun) +..'cause I wear the badge in this bleep county. So you listen good, you bleep-bleep, bleep-bleep... ires gun, same shot) ..-if I ever see you or any one of you other bleep in this town again, I'il knock you so flat you'll have to bleep-bleep, bleep-bleep, eep! bleep- Dp (fires gun, same shot) Ed Earl and Mona watch in open-mouthed horror.
MELVIN (v.o.) Is this the kind of man we want running our law enforcement? Is this the kind of foul-mouthed example we want to set for our children? Mona sadly shakes her head.
Ed Earl, that man has made a fool of you. Ed Earl, in shock, absently hangs up the phone.
The Mayor, Edsel and C.J. Vernon are pacing around Ed Ear outer office. The two phones are ringing and Rita has her hands full. Deputy Fred waits. The Mayor takes out his watch.
I've had calls from four preachers, six deacons and the presidents of two garden clubs.
(hanging up) The phones have been ringing just like that all morning.
Don't know why I let people talk me into serving as the Mayor of this incorporated sand trap anyway. (looking at his watch) What the heck is keeping him?
He'1li be along.
My wife couldn't believe what she saw last night. They bleeped him out, but she read his lips on every ‘hell', 'goddamn' and 'shit'.
Did you hear some folks are getting up a petition to close the Chicken Ranch?
75 122 c.J. All we wanted to do was keep it iet. Now, thanks to Ed Earl, it's getting to be the hottest thing on the air since The Gong Show. Ed Earl enters and stops at Rita's desk for his messages.
Mornin', Sheriff. Here's your calls.
Mornin', Rita. Mornin’, fellers. I guess you're waiting to talk to me.
We sure are. You don't know the trouble you've stirred up with this Chicken Ranch business. They follow Ed Earl into his office.
Dammit, Ed Earl, if you aren't a pluperfect fool.
Maybe so. I've got calls here from a dozen shocked citizens telling me we've got a whorehouse operating in this county...for about a hundred and fifty years!

Ed Earl, you can set up speed traps to catch the tourists, you can look the other way when the wrong kid swipes a car to go joyriding, hell, you can even allow Miss Mona to run her place out there. But the one thing you can't get away with is broadcastin' gutter talk on TV!
How was I supposed to know they were taking pictures?
76 1 c.J. What did you figure the cameras were for?

You know, I'm getting just a little sick of all this bad mouthin'. Hell, the Chicken Ranch don't give me half as much trouble as those all night stag parties out at the Legionnaires Hall. c.g. (embarrassed) That ain't fair, ding it!
There's only one thing to do and that's close the place down before we all go to hell in a handbasket.

Close it down! Oh, you were all willing to go along with Miss Mona when things were running good because she brought business to the town and made civic contributions. But now that she's in trouble, you're all about to turn tail and run like rats from a burning barn.
That's just it, Ed Earl. But who's going to put out the fire?
Look, if you won't close her down, at least tell her to lay low for a couple of months. C.J. Just until the heat wears off.
Give it two months. What's two months? :
Dammit, Rufus. I don't want anybody telling me how to do my job. I'm still the law here and I'll make up my own mind about what's gotta be done!
Ed Earl is talking to Mona.
Two months. What's two months?
Shut down for two months! That's a hell of a lot of overhead to pay out when a company's cash is not coming in. What am I supposed to tell my girls?
Maybe it won't be two months. The holidays are coming up. Maybe in a couple of weeks it will have all blown over and you can start letting your regular customers in the back door.
You know, I warned you before you left yesterday about losing your temper...shouting and carrying on.
Last night you said you were proud of me.
Last night I wasn't on the eleven o'clock news!
I didn't know they were going to make me out to look like an idiot. I don't understand this electronic bullshit. How was I supposed to handle it?
That's your job. That's what you're paid for.

I know what my job is. I know I can have this whole place shut down in a New York minute. But all I'm asking for is a little cooperation from you so we can get through this difficult situation with as little trouble as possible.
Okay. Okay. I'11 shut down.
You promise?
What do you want, a written contract? I give you my word.
I'm really sorry this had to happen.
Don't feel sorry for me. I started out poor and worked my way up to outcast.

Mona, I hate this, dammit, I really do. I don't want this to hurt our relationship, but I. really believe this is the best answer. If you'll just trust me. Mona is quite moved with his honest expression of emotion She turns, smiles, and gives him a kiss.
Oh, you big cowboy, I do trust you. Ain't I always? She gives him a hug. He kisses her lightly on the cheek and, with a flourish, puts on his hat. He turns and opens the door.
Ed Earl is coming down the stairs just as Jewel, carrying pile of sheets, is coming up.
Well, if it ain't the celebrated cussing Sheriff of Lanville County. How are you Sheriff?
Fine. How are you, Porky?
(laughing) Now, Sheriff, I been real good all week. I dropped six pounds.
What did you do, lose a finger? Ed Earl] continues down the stairs and out the door. Jewe laughing, walks up to Mona.
I've just promised the Sheriff to shut the place down for two months.
What? How can you promise that? What about the football game celebration tomorrow night?
Oh, I forgot.
It's the Thanksgiving game, Miss Mona. That's real special.
Yes, I know. Well, okay. But we'll be closed for all regulars. Do you think that'll be all right? JEWEL © I'm sure it will, honey. That party's a tradition.
The traditional Thanksgiving Day rivalry between the Texa Aggies and the Texas Longhorns 18 in full swing.
The ANNOUNCER, looking down over the field, is talking in the microphone.

Well folks, this game has turned into a real stem-winder, The Texas Aggies, favored to lock up the Southwest Conference and waltz into the Cotton Bowl in Dallas for a happy New Year, are fighting for their football lives.

on the field, we see regular football action as the Announcer's voice continues. ANNOUNCER (v.0.) The Longhorns are playing tough defensive ‘ball, making this traditional Thanksgiving Day classic one for the record s books.

Ed Earl and Billy are watching the game on the television the living room. Thanksgiving decorations are on the mant In the kitchen, Dulcie Mae takes the turkey out of the ov she Looks over at her son sitting happily with Ed Earl on couch.
Come on, Aggies, plow those Longhorns! ‘ga Earl laughs and pops a beer.
‘Some of the girls are putting up the decorations while the TV with the football game plays in the parlor. Out in the hall, Angel is on the phone.

Well, I sure do hope Mummy will be home for Christmas, punkin'. Now you have a good Thanksgiving and put Grandma back on...Mummy loves you, baby.... Jewel walks by with double sets of colored crepe paper ribbons and holds them up for the girls in the main room.
We'll string up the white first and then see who wins before we add the orange or maroon.
I cain't stand it if them Aggies win.
What do you mean?
They're such animals. Always yelling and jumping about and saying 'Yeee-haaw!'
I like that.
We had two Aggies here last year. They went upstairs to shoot craps -- and blew a hole in the toilet. The girls all laugh, but Shy is a little backward.
Really? What did Miss Mona say?
She's putting you on, darlin’.
The hell I am. Those boys are dumb.
Dumb ain't the word. You hear about the time the Aggie coach went up to the quarterback and asked him, ‘Do you think you can pass this ball?' ‘Hell, yes,' said the Aggie quarterback.
(laughing together ) If I can swallow it. The girls all join in laughing and now Shy sees that they are making Aggie jokes. She smiles. Ginger looks over at the television set.
Come on, Longhorns! Hold that line!  131 132 133 134

What a finish we've got here, folks. The Aggies are out of the huddle, twenty short ticks of the clock from oblivion. The underdog Longhorns lead twelve to seven, with the Aggies in business on the thirty-five yard line.

We see the play as it is described. ANNOUNCER (v.o.) Bubba Shrake takes the snap and drops back to pass. He's got good protection...he's looking deep. Shrake throws over the middie. (shouts) Sliney's got it at the five! He's hit and he's short of the goalline. He's stopped short! And he calls time! Time out on the field with three seconds left.
Two ENGINEERS are watching the game on monitors.
I'll bet those boys are creaming in their pants. You know that whichever team wins gets a celebration dinner tonight at the Chicken Ranch.

Yeah. Course, it don't matter what the scoreboard says, the real winner of today's game is gonna be Miss Mona. They laugh. We pan off the Enginerrs and see that Melvin has overheard their conversation. He looks up at the monitor and smiles with gleeful expectation.
Just three seconds left on the scoreboard clock. The Aggies trailing twelve to seven on the five-yard line, needing a touchdown to win.

The Aggies come down into the locker room, all breathless and excited.
Yeeeehaaaw! Senator Wingwood and the alumni welcome them.

Boys! Boys! That was the greatest victory since General Eisenhower . won! You make me glad to be an Aggie. I swear, I could break down and cry like a baby, I'm so flushed with pride.... one of the Aggies is tossing bottles of Lone Star Beer to his teammates as they enter. He tosses one to the Senator
Have a Lone Star on us, Senator.

Now, you boys know senators don't drink! It ain't good for the Baptist vote. He pops it open and it sprays across the room. One of the Aggies does a few bars of a foot-stompin' cleat dance. Th others cheer for him. A lot of “yee-haw's."
Hey, Senator, you ain't forgot you was gonna take us to the Chicken Ranch, have you?
(leering) I always keep my campaign promises! Cheers from the team.

yes sir, the Chicken Ranch is a fine institution and I'm proud to have it in my district. And to hell with what Melvin P. Thorpe says. So let's get a move on and we'll see you boys at Miss Mona's. He and his party exit.

The Aggies all cheer and the true celebration starts. The are pulling off their pads and uniforms. Various angles o the different players like LEROY SLINEY, the young wide receiver, and BARNEY SCRUGGS, the ox-like defensive lineman. They begin to sing.

(singing) We're gonna whomp And stomp And whoop it up tonight Those little gals won't never ever Be the same. They're gonna love it when we whomp And stomp And whoop it up all right It's even better than an Aggie Football game.
(dumbly) Better than a football game?
Various angles of the Aggies showering.

And then we're gonna show them all A thing or two We're gonna demonstrate Just what A champion can do Yee-Haw! We're gonna play 'em out and Lay ‘em out tonight They won't have never seen nobody Quite like me -- huh.
The Aggies come out of the showers and, snapping their towels and horsing around, go to their lockers to begin getting dressed.
We're gonna wham and bam and Thank you ma'am tonight I swear I don't know how they'll Stand such ecstasy -- huh Right between the goalpost.
They put on their blue jeans and cowboy boots and sing.
We been deprived so long But now we're gettin’ some I bet the girls are countin' up The minutes 'til we come. An Aggie pops up from behind a locker.
They ain't the only ones. Peach-fuzzed, clear-voiced Leroy Sliney pushes a laundry cart down the middle of the locker room.
Seventy-five miles until we get to heaven.

Seventy-five miles until our Plans are laid Seventy-five miles until we get to The Chicken Ranch Where history _And Aggie boys Get made. The boys spin the cart around and begin the big dance num After a spectacular series of acrobatics and clogging, th Aggies, now fully dressed with shirts and hats, charge ou of the front door.
From a helicopter we see the Aggie bus driving down a country road. We push in just as Leroy sticks his head ou a window.
Twenty-two miles until we get To heaven. Other Aggies stick their heads out.
Twenty-two miles until our Plans are laid Twenty-two miles until we get To the Chicken Ranch.  142 143 144 145
The whole team, with their hats in their hands, joyfully sticks their heads out the windows.
Where history And Aggie boys Get made. The rear tire blows out and the truck careens to a halt b the side of the road.
Jewel is distributing some of the ball gowns to the girls Shy picks one up and is admiring it, but Ginger is very bored with the idea.
Do we have to wear these ball gowns again?
Yes, you do, and I don't want to hear any bitchin' about it. Miss Mona tries to create something special for these boys -- it's like a graduation dance.

Silhouetted against the setting sun, the Aggies are packe stacked and hanging all over a small pickup truck driven a somewhat confused old farmer. Leroy is holding onto the roof with one hand and sings excitedly.
One more mile until we get To heaven.
One more mile until our Plans are laid.
The pickup truck drives up the hill to the front gate.

One more mile until we get To the Chicken Ranch Where history And Aggie boys Get made. Leaping and jumping off the pickup truck, the Aggies danc up to the front porch and knock on the Chicken Ranch door

Jewel opens the door and welcomes them. They enter polite hats in hand. Senator Wingwood has already arrived and he greets them when suddenly all heads turn to Miss Mona as makes one of her grand entrances down the stairs.
(to Mona) Howdy, ma'am. I'm Senator Wingwood of the 19th District and Aggie Class of '49. Mighty proud to meetcha.
Meet me? Come on, Charlie. How's Mary Margaret and the kids? The Aggies all laugh and the Senator is momentarily embarrassed.
Hell, Miss Mona. I didn't think you'd remember.
You remember to bring the check?
1 got it right here. He produces it from his coat pocket and hands it to her.
It's a business doing pleasure with you, Senator. She rings the bell.
Come on, boys. We've got a surprise for you. She leads everyone out to the back.  147 148

Miss Mona enters with the Aggies as the girls are coming down the backstairs or waiting beneath the colored lanter strung out over the punch bowl. They are all wearing thei ball gowns and look slightly reminiscent of a high school prom. The Aggies break into whistles and catcalls and beg pairing off for an encore of the Aggie dance. Leroy spots Shy and he pairs up with her. Mona signals Ginger to take the Senator off her hands. The high point of the number comes when the girls snap of their bali gowns (held in place by Velcro) and appear in their latest Frederick's of Hollywood underwear.

Yeeeehaaaaw! The stomping becomes frenetic and the dance ends with the couples facing off inside or upstairs looking for a bedro The Senator goes with Ginger. Leroy goes off with Shy. Mona looks over at Jewel, gives her a look that says "Wel that's that," and turns off the party lights.
Ed Earl is leaving after having Thanksgiving dinner with Dulcie Mae.
Thank you for spending time with Billy. He really idolizes you.
Yeah, I know. He's a great kid. And you're a great cook.
Yeah, I know. They laugh.
I hope everything works out with this Melvin P. Thorpe business. I know it's been worrying you.
It'll all blow over soon.
Of course it will. After all, the Chicken Ranch has been there for years. And Miss Mona...well, she does a lot of good in town.
Yes. She does. (pause) Well, it's late. (kisses her on the cheek) Thank you, Dulcie. You're real sweet and you're real special to me.
Thank you, Ed Earl.
Good night, honey. He hops in his car and drives home.

Deputy Fred is making his rounds, walking across the deserted town square. A TV van goes by. He stops and looks. A car follows. He looks again. Melvin P. Thorpe in the Watchdog van drives by. The Deputy scratches his head and thinks about that for a moment.
Mona is in her bedroom going over her accounts. She opens her ledgers and sits at her desk.

location: A ROOM IN THE CHICKEN RANCH

text: Leroy is contentedly smoking a cigarette. We pan over at Shy looking at him demurely from the pillow.
Jewel has her feet up watching an old movie on television The house is very quiet.
Ed Earl, in his boxer shorts, is brushing his teeth getti ready for bed. There is a knock at the front door. He goe to answer it.
Ed Earl crosses the living room, turning on the lights as goes. He opens the door. It's Deputy Fred.
Good evening, Sheriff.
This better be important.
Well, I think it is. I was making my rounds in town when I just saw that Melvin P. Thorpe drive through with some other fellers on their way to the Chicken Ranch.
Well, he's going to be real disappointed. There's nothing going on up there. Miss Mona's shut down for two months on my orders.
No, she ain't, Sheriff. Hell... (laughs) I saw those Aggie boys up there tonight celebrating to beat the band.
Huh? Huh...Holy shit!

Everyone has gone to bed. The lights are low. We pan down from Mona at her desk in her bedroom to shadows creeping along the Chicken Ranch wall. It is Melvin and his crew o cameramen and reporters (eight in all). They reach the lattice door to the backyard and, with a pair of chain eutters, cut the lock. Melvin turns to the camera, signal to switch it on and addresses his audience. MELVIN . Now we're going to take you into the whorehouse itself.
Melvin and his crew creep along the back porch and sneak inside.
They pass the parlor where Jewel has fallen asleep in fro of a television station that has gone off the air. Melvin
positions his men near the light switches, then stands by the bell and gives the signal.

Okay, everybody up! The bel] clangs, all the lights in the house turn on and with a charging yell, Melvin and his crew go running up t stairs and through the whorehouse. Jewel wakes up and fal off her chair.
Mona looks up and reacts to the noise.

The still photographers throw open the doors and burst in snapping pictures with flash cameras of couples in bed. Girls scream, boys jump out of bed and start putting on their clothes, knocking over tables and water bowls as th do so.
Melvin bursts into a room, followed by his cameraman. He turns to address his television audience while the startl customer in bed looks around.
Now we're going to talk to some of the girls and their customers.
The place is in pandemonium. Boys and girls are running everywhere, screaming and shouting "raid." Mona comes out of her room and sees Jewel coming up the stairs.
What's going on?

It's that Melvin P. Thorpe sucker and his TV reporters. Mona runs back into her room while Jewel grabs a still ph rapher who is running by her and starts belting him in th mouth. One of his friends comes to his assistance and Jew karate chops him over the bannister.  wm 162 163 164 165 oo 166 167 o~
Mona dials the Sheriff's office to bring assistance.

A montage of shots. An Aggie gets out from under a bed asking, "What's up?" Another Aggie leaves his girl, sayin “wait until next year" and rushes off. We see a foursome bed surprised by a photographer, while in another room a and girl are so stoned out on a joint that they look arou and mutter "Far out!"

Oh, Ed Earl, I've loved you since I was a sixteen-year-old baby and I'll keep on lovin' you ‘til they bury me. They kiss...lovingly and passionately. Mona breaks away.

Mona, didn't you hear what I said? She hushes him with her fingers on hie lips.

I did, my darlin', but it's always going to be the way it is. You'll always be the Sheriff -- and you should be because you're good at your job -- and I'll always be...just what I am. You know it and I know it. It just wouldn't work.
But we can make it work. I don't give a damn what people say, we've got to give it a chance...please. Don't leave.

(singing) If I should stay I would only be in your way And go I'11 go and yet I know That I'11 think of you each step of the way And I will always love you I will always love you. Bitter sweet memories I guess that's all I'll be taking with me Good-bye, oh please don't cry ‘Cause we both know that I'm not what you need But I will always love you I will always love you. (talking) And I hope life will treat you kind And I hope that you have ali that you've ever dreamed of.
I wish you joy, I wish you happiness But above all this I wish you love I love you, and I will always love you. Ed Earl turns and exits. Mona begins to sing, but breaks before the song is finished.
(singing) 1 will always love you I will always love you, I'll always love you....
Jewel comes up to the front porch and speaks softly to Mona.
Come on, honey. It's time to go. Mona brushes away her tears and exits by Jewel, who pulls the front door shut.
Jewel starts up the car and drives down the road. Mona is sadly sitting beside her.

Jewel looks into the rearview mirror and sees the Chicken Ranch receding in the background. She looks over at Mona who is lost in her own thoughts. Jewel looks out ahead an sees something that makes her smile. She glances over at Mona again, then smiles some more.

We pull back from the red light on top of the Sheriff's c and see Ed Earl, with his jacket off and his badge prominently pinned to his shirt, step out of the car and walk around to halt the approaching vehicle.
Mona looks forward and sees Ed Earl with his hand raised a resolute look of authority on his face. Despite her tears, she breaks into a smile.

Jewel stops the car and we pull back as Ed Earl walks ove to Mona and opens her door. The Narrator begins singing a as we swing around and fly higher we see the little house all closed and shuttered sitting forlornly on top of the hill.
Oh, the little house lay ina Green Texas glade Where the trees were as coolin' As fresh lemonade Soft summer wind Had a trace of perfume And a fan was turnin' In every room.
Twenty fane were turnin’ They were turnin' Twenty fans were turnin’ In every room Fevers were a-burnin' They were burnin' And they had to have A way to cool down.
It was just a little old bitty pissant country place....
The music begins a foot-stompin' reprise of the songs as we flash short cuts of highlights from the film. At the end the credits, Mona turns to camera.
Ya'll come back now, you hear?
